HTML & CSS Challenges

  • Don't describe an image in an alt tag as 'an image of' ...the thing. Screen reader users will know its an image.
  • <head> <links> and <body> anchors use href not src.
  • Set font-size on typography tags (a, p, h1, etc), not parent elements. They will scale proportionally if you do. A font-size on a header will set the font-size for that header. Set it on the h1!
  • Typography tags (a, p, h1, etc) have default margin to and bottom.
  • If you don't style a border-color it will be the same color as your font.
Get Emoji ü¶ë

Intro to JavaScript

this
if else

The Boolean Question

if declaring a boolean value, frame the variable name as a question. eg.

                
var isOldEnoughToDrive = false 
var isSubscribed = true

Method

Function: a type of data that allows us to execute specific code when/as needed

Method: A function that is a property of an object


sayGreeting is a Method of larry

                
var larry = {
  name: "larry",
  age: 20,
  friends: ["john", "lisa", "al"],
  isPetOwner: true,
  sayGreeting: function(){
      console.log("Hello")
  }
}

console.log(larry.name)
console.log(larry.sayGreeting)
larry.sayGreeting()
                
              
                
‚Ä∫larry
‚Ä∫∆í()
‚Ä∫Hello

this

this keyword inside of an object refers to itself 

                
var larry = {
  name: "larry",
  age: 20,
  friends: ["john", "lisa", "al"],
  isPetOwner: true,
  greeting: "Hello Friend!",
  sayGreeting: function(){
      console.log(this.greeting)
  }
}

larry.sayGreeting()
                
              
                
‚Ä∫Hello Friend!

myObject

                
var submarine = {
  crew: 6,
  captain: "Archibold",
  officers: ["Fred", "Simon", "Gregory"],
  isSubmerged: true,
  torpedoSound: "Spluuuuurrshhhh...BANG!!!",
  fireTorpedo: function(){
      console.log(this.torpedoSound)
  }
}
    
console.log(submarine.captain);
console.log(submarine.officers[1]);
console.log(submarine.isSubmerged);
console.log(submarine["crew"]);
console.log(submarine.fireTorpedo); // logs function 

submarine.fireTorpedo() // executes function
                
              
                
‚Ä∫Archibold
‚Ä∫Simon
‚Ä∫true
‚Ä∫6
‚Ä∫∆í()
‚Ä∫Spluuuuurrshhhh...BANG!!!

Bracket Notation needs to be in "quotes"

Josh Comeau Operator Lookup

Nested if / else statement

First check that the username and password variables have values?

Then check that both are correct

if not, say so.

                
var username = "joe"
var password = "joe123"
                  
// nested if else
if(!username || !password){
    console.log("Please provide username and password")
} else {
    if(username === "joe" && password === "joe123"){
        console.log("Access granted")
    } else {
        console.log("Username or password are incorrect") 
    }
}

Intro to Loops

for
for...in
for...of

Classic & for...of

                
const europe = ['Sweden', 'Norway', 'Bulgaria', 'France', 'Germany', 'Poland']

// classic
for (let i = 0; i < europe.length; i++ ) {
  console.log(europe[i])
}

// for...of     use on arrays, strings, NodeLists, TypedArrays, Maps & Sets
for(const i of europe){
  console.log(i)
}
                
              
                
‚Ä∫Sweden
‚Ä∫Norway
‚Ä∫Bulgaria
‚Ä∫France
‚Ä∫Germany
‚Ä∫Poland

‚Ä∫Sweden
‚Ä∫Norway
‚Ä∫Bulgaria
‚Ä∫France
‚Ä∫Germany
‚Ä∫Poland

for..in loop for objects

                
const europe = ['Sweden', 'Norway', 'Bulgaria', 'France', 'Germany', 'Poland']

// for...in     use on objects instead of arrays
for(let i in europe){
  console.log(europe[i])
}

for(let i in europe){
  console.log(i)
}

for(let i in europe){
  console.log(i + " - " + europe[i])
}

const object = { a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 };

for (const property in object) {
console.log(`${property}: ${object[property]}`);
}
                
              
                
‚Ä∫Sweden
‚Ä∫Norway
‚Ä∫Bulgaria
‚Ä∫France
‚Ä∫Germany
‚Ä∫Poland
‚Ä∫0
‚Ä∫1
‚Ä∫2
‚Ä∫3
‚Ä∫4
‚Ä∫5
‚Ä∫0 - Sweden
‚Ä∫1 - Norway
‚Ä∫2 - Bulgaria
‚Ä∫3 - France
‚Ä∫4 - Germany
‚Ä∫5 - Poland
‚Ä∫a: 1
‚Ä∫b: 2
‚Ä∫c: 3

Loop with if statement

                
const tableNumbers = [5, 14, 7, 10, 20, 11, 12, 15, 3]

for (let i =0; i < tableNumbers.length; i++) {
    if (tableNumbers[i] % 2 === 0) {
        console.log(tableNumbers[i])
    }
}
Speed dating. Which of these tables is divisible by 2? 
                
‚Ä∫14
‚Ä∫10
‚Ä∫20
‚Ä∫12

Chessboard

                
const squares = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.grid div'))
                  
for (let i = 0; i <= squares.length; i++){
  if(i % 2 === 0){
      squares[i].style.background = "#fff"
  }
}

// for (const element of squares){
//     console.log(element)
//     if(element % 2 === 0){
//         element.style.background = "red"
//     }
// }

for...of doesn't work here because it will keep iterating through 'div', not a number

loops & arrays

                
const shopInventory = ['milk', 'Cheddar', 'musTaRd',
 'mustard', 'muuustard', 'ketchup', 'olive oil',
  'cheddar', 'milk', 'garlic', 'mayo', 'carrots',
   'cheddar', 'Mustard', 'mayo', 'orange juice']

let count = 0

for (let i = 0; i < shopInventory.length; i++) {
    if (shopInventory[i].toLowerCase() === 'mustard') {
        count ++ 
    }
}

console.log(count)
                
              
                
3
Aaaall the mustard. toLowerCase

body {
  background-color: #FFCCF9;
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
}

.grid {
  margin-top: 30px;
  width: 360px;
  height: 360px;
  border: solid white 8px;
  border-radius: 5px;
  display: flex;
  flex-wrap: wrap;
}

.grid div {
  width: 20px;
  height: 20px;
}

.wall {
  background-color: #6EB5FF;
}

.power-pellet {
  background-color: #FFABAB;
  border-radius: 10px;
}

.pac-dot {
  background-color: white;
  border: 5px solid #FFCCF9; /* BOX-SIZING  to make smaller*/
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

.pac-man {
  background-color: yellow;
  border-radius: 10px;
}

.inky {background-color: cyan;}
.blinky {background-color: red;}
.pinky {background-color: pink;}
.clyde {background-color: orange;}

for (let i = 0; i < squares.length; i++) {
    if (layout[i] === 1) squares[i].classList.add('wall')
    if (layout[i] === 2) squares[i].classList.add('pac-dot')
    if (layout[i] === 3) squares[i].classList.add('power-pellet')
    if (layout[i] === 4) squares[i].classList.add('pac-man')
    if (layout[i] === 5) squares[i].classList.add('blinky')
    if (layout[i] === 6) squares[i].classList.add('inky')
    if (layout[i] === 7) squares[i].classList.add('pinky')
    if (layout[i] === 8) squares[i].classList.add('clyde')
}

  text-align: center;

  background-color: #FFBEBC;
}

  background-color: #FFF5BA;
  font-family: sans-serif;
}
                
              
                
const squares = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.grid div'))

console.log(squares)

const layout = [
    's','c','r','a','b','b','l','e','','','','','',
    '','o','','','','','','','','','','','',
    '','w','i','n','n','e','r','','','','','','',
    '','','','','','','i','','','','','','',
    '','','','','','','n','','','','','','',
    '','','','','','','g','o','a','t','','','',
    '','','','','','','','','','','','','',
    '','','','','','','','','','','','','',
    '','','','','','','','','','','','','',
    '','','','','','','','','','','','','',
    '','','','','','','','','','','','','',
    '','','','','','','','','','','','','',
    '','','','','','','','','','','','','',
]
// Ania's Solution
// declare a variable to store the letter
// innerHTML
// style the div with a class

for (let i=0; i < squares.length; i++) {
    let letter = layout[i]
    squares[i].innerHTML = letter
    if (letter !== '') squares[i].classList.add('tile')
}

// My Solution
for(let i = 0; i < squares.length; i++){
  if(layout[i] !== '') 
      squares[i].classList.add('tile') 
      squares[i].textContent = layout[i]
}

Remember 'i' in loops is a number not a property

DON'T USE innerHTML

Functions and Methods

function()
slice()

Functions with parameters

                
function showAlert(firstName, lastName) {
  console.log( firstName + ' ' + lastName +  ', you have been alerted')
}
showAlert('Ania', 'Kubow')
showAlert('Ania') //missing
showAlert('Ahmed', 'Abdul', 'Aziz') //extra
                
              
                
‚Ä∫Ania Kubow, you have been alerted
‚Ä∫Ania undefined, you have been alerted
‚Ä∫Ahmed Abdul, you have been alerted

Calling functions that are missing parameters will return undefined for the missing ones. Adding extra parameters will be ignored.

Move Robot

                
const robot = document.querySelector('.robot')

// Challenge: Make the robot move when you click it. 

let number = 0

function moveRobot() {
    number += 50
    console.log(number)
    robot.style.left = number + 'px'
}
robot.addEventListener('click', moveRobot)
                
              
                
‚Ä∫50
‚Ä∫100
‚Ä∫150
‚Ä∫200

Initialize variable

Increment

Update style

RANDOM Numbers

random range
                
const items = 10

let randomNumber = Math.random() * items
console.log(randomNumber)

let newNumber = Math.floor(randomNumber)
console.log(newNumber)

let betweenOneAndTwenty = Math.floor(Math.random() * (20+1))
console.log(betweenOneAndTwenty + " is between one and twenty")

let betweenOneAndThree = Math.floor(Math.random() * (3+1))
console.log(betweenOneAndThree + " is between one and three")
                
              
                
‚Ä∫7.0284182670022055
‚Ä∫7
‚Ä∫18 is between one and twenty
‚Ä∫3 is between one and three

BEWARE the floating number!

Add 1 to get a random range including that number

random array
                
const shopItems = ['dog biscuits', 'collar', 'bones', 'toy']
let randomNumber = Math.random() * shopItems.length // 4
console.log(randomNumber)

let newNumber = Math.floor(randomNumber)
console.log(newNumber)

let randomItem = shopItems[newNumber] // 0-3
console.log(randomItem)
                
              
                
‚Ä∫3.594807922371296
‚Ä∫3
‚Ä∫toy

remember zero indexing

When getting a random array element Don't add 1.

random quotes from array
                
const quoteDisplay = document.querySelector('#quote')
const button = document.querySelector('button')

//Challenge: Write a function that will display a random Inspirational Quote
//from the quotes array, when the button is pressed.
const quotes = [
    'Do something today that your future self will thankyou for',
    'Dont worry, be happy!',
    'Your limitation is only your imagination',
    'üíÄMercy is for the weak!üíÄ',
    'Failure is the greatest teacher'
]

function showQuote() {
    //your code
    let randomNumber = Math.floor(Math.random() * quotes.length)
    console.log(randomNumber)
    quoteDisplay.textContent = quotes[randomNumber]
}

Slice

                
const films = ['Elf', 'Borat', 'It', 'Split', 'Us']

//get the last 2 films from the array and put them in the thriller section
const thriller = films.slice(3, 5)
console.log(thriller)

//get the 3rd and 4th film from the array and put them in the horror section
const horror = films.slice(2,4)
console.log(horror)

//get the first 2 films from the array and put them in the comedy section
const comedy = films.slice(0,2)
console.log(comedy)

console.log(films)
                
              
                
‚Ä∫["Split", "Us"]
‚Ä∫["It", "Split"]
‚Ä∫["Elf", "Borat"]
‚Ä∫["Elf", "Borat", "It", "Split", "Us"]

Start index end index

Not mutable method

Creates New Arrays

Add elements to an Array

.unshift()

Adds to front

                
let lottery = [5, 7, 8, 10, 12]

const number = 34

lottery.unshift(number)

console.log(lottery)
                
              
                
‚Ä∫[34, 5, 7, 8, 10, 12]

.push()

Adds to back

                
let books = ['Moby Dick', 'Life of Pi', 'Sapiens']

books.push('The Hungry Caterpillar')

console.log(books)
                
              
                
‚Ä∫["Moby Dick", "Life of Pi", "Sapiens", "The Hungry Caterpillar"]

Remove elements from an Array

.shift()

removes from front

                
let cars = [
  {name: 'ford', colour: 'black'},
  {name: 'volkswagen', colour: 'blue'},  
  {name: 'aston martin', colour: 'red'}
]

let car = cars.shift()

console.log(car)
console.log(cars)
                
              
                
‚Ä∫{name: "ford", colour: "black"}
‚Ä∫[{name: "volkswagen", colour: "blue"}, {name: "aston martin", colour: "red"}]

Can store elements with .shift()

.pop()

removes from back

                
let planets = ['Earth', 'Mars', 'Saturn', 'Uranus', 'Pluto']

let removedPlanet = planets.pop()

console.log(removedPlanet)
console.log(planets)
                
              
                
‚Ä∫Pluto
‚Ä∫["Earth", "Mars", "Saturn", "Uranus"]

Can store elements with .pop()

Intro to the DOM

innerText
textContent
Array.from()
document.getElementsByClassName('things')
document.getElementsByTagName('h1')
document.getElementById('things')
document.querySelector("#test")
document.querySelectorAll("div.highlighted > p")

innerText vs. textContent

innerText returns the visible text contained in a node "expensive, labour intensive"

textContent returns the full text including those hidden by a CSS style

innerHTML SECURITY RISK!

see below for example

Getting objects / elements

                
// plural 
let things = document.getElementsByClassName('things')
let headers = document.getElementsByTagName('h1')

// singular (id)
let thing = document.getElementById('things')

// specific (query selector)
// needs css markup eg . # attributes
let container = document.querySelector("#test");
let matches = document.querySelectorAll("div.highlighted > p");

Getting elements by class name & tag name return HTMLCollections

Query Selectors return nodelists

Remember to use Array.from() to get an actual array.

Not finding an element by id will return null

                
let things = Array.from()document.getElementsByClassName('things')

let matches = Array.from()container.querySelectorAll("div.highlighted > p")

the document in DOM

The DOM is a JavaScript object that represents the document (web page). It provide a set of tools for the developer to use to manipulate the web page.

open the dev tools an type the following

                
console.log(document) //or...
console.dir(document)

Array.from()
forEach()

loop through Array. Redacted kittens

                
var result = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll("ol#favorite-things > li"))
console.log(result)

//es6
result.forEach(elem => elem.textContent = 'redacted')

//old
result.forEach(function(item){
  item.textContent = 'redacted'
})

Array.from not actually needed on node collection.

typeof
Object.keys()

Modifying Text and Styles

üó£ ModifyingTexts

                
<body>
  <h1>Here is some text</h1>
  <p>PLACEHOLDER</p>
  
  <script src="index.js"></script>
</body>

change paragraph to the same as the header.

                
// grab
let heading = document.querySelector('h1')
let para = document.querySelector('p')

// save
let newText = heading.textContent

// alter
para.textContent = newText

// neater, better
var text = document.querySelector("#header").textContent
document.querySelector("#paragraph").textContent = text

Here is some text

Here is some text

Individual Objects

                
var header = document.getElementById("header")
var heading = document.getElementById("header").textContent

console.log(typeof header)
console.log(typeof heading)


console.log(Object.keys(header.style))
                
              
                
‚Ä∫object
‚Ä∫string
‚Ä∫["alignContent", "alignItems", "alignSelf", "alignmentBaseline", 
"all", "animation", "animationDelay", "animationDirection", 
"animationDuration", "animationFillMode", "animationIterationCount",
 "animationName", "animationPlayState", "animationTimingFunction", 
 "appearance", "ascentOverride", "backdropFilter", 
 "backfaceVisibility", "background", "backgroundAttachment", 
 "backgroundBlendMode", "backgroundClip", "backgroundColor", 
 "backgroundImage", "backgroundOrigin", "backgroundPosition", 
 "backgroundPositionX", "backgroundPositionY", "backgroundRepeat",
  "backgroundRepeatX", ...]

Use typeof to determine an element.

header is an object

heading is a string

Use Object.keys() to see all available properties of that object.

Modifying objects

                
var header = document.getElementById("header")
header.style.backgroundColor = "blue"

Remember to camelCase your .styles ! eg. backgroundColor or textAlign

üó£ Modifying className / classList

                
<h1 id="header" class="title another">Modifying Styles with JS</h1>
                
              
                
// log className
console.log(document.querySelector("#header").className)

//toggle classList
document.querySelector("#header").classList.toggle("another")

// log className(s)
console.log(document.querySelector("#header").className)
                
              
                
‚Ä∫title another
‚Ä∫title

From MDM: "Using classList is a convenient alternative to accessing an element's list of classes as a space-delimited string via element.className.""

üó£ Modifying Value (inputs)

                
  <input type="text" id="text-input" value="This is some content"/>

inputs are self closing tags, but do have value attributes, which store content and can be modified.

                
  var inputBox = document.getElementById("text-input")
  inputBox.value = "CHANGED!"

Creating Elements

document.createElement('p')
.append()
.prepend()
Add to a list

Create element. Give it a text content.

                  
<ul id="my-list">
  <li>0</li>
  <li>1</li>
  <li>2</li>
</ul>

Warning Differentiate between an element and its text content

                  
// ERROR... this is just the number 3
var newLi = document.createElement("li").textContent = 3

// the new li saved to a variable
var newLi = document.createElement("li")
// the existing list saved to a variable
var myList = document.getElementById("my-list")

// add text content
newLi.textContent = '3' 

console.log(newLi) // <li>
console.log(newLi.textContent) // 3

//append
myList.append(newLi)
                  
                
                  
‚Ä∫<li>
‚Ä∫3
                  
                
                  
// proper way
// create element 
var newLi = document.createElement("li")
// assign element a text content
newLi.textContent = "3"
//grab original list
var myList = document.getElementById("my-list")
// append or prepend
myList.append(newLi)
  • 0
  • 1
  • 2
  • 3

Warning Append / Prepend to the correct element / parent element

                  
const newPara = document.createElement('p')
newPara.textContent = 'Lorem ipsum prattle nonsense'

// ERROR... appends to the list
myList.append(newPara)

// appends to the body
document.body.append(newPara)

Appending a paragraph

Warning Append / Prepend to the correct element / parent element

Note: document.body is unique in that it needs no selector. All other elements will need to be grabbed by selectors.

innerHTML vs innerText vs textContent

inner text is the most labour intensive but will account for hidden elements (ie. not reveal them). Don't set innerHTML as a variable. But you can update it as below (i think?).

                  
<ul id="my-list">
  <li>0</li>
  <li>1</li>
  <li>2</li>
</ul>
                  
                
                  
li:first-child {
  display: none;
}
                  
                
                  
// innerHTML vs innerText vs textContent
var myList = document.getElementById("my-list")

console.log(myList.textContent)
console.log(myList.innerText) // account for hidden
console.log(myList.innerHTML)

myList.innerHTML += "
  • 3
    • "

console.log(myList.innerHTML)
                      
                
                      
‚Ä∫0 1 2
‚Ä∫1 2
‚Ä∫<li>0</li> <li>1</li> <li>2</li>
‚Ä∫<li>0</li> <li>1</li> <li>2</li> <li>3</li>
    üëä append() vs appendChild() üëä
    append()
    • accepts Node objects and DOMStrings
    • allows you to add multiple item
    • No return Value
    appendChild()
    • accepts only Node objects (no text content)
    • allows only a single item
    • returns the appended Node object
                      
const parent = document.createElement('div');
const child = document.createElement('p');
// Appending Node Objects
parent.append(child) // Works fine
parent.appendChild(child) // Works fine
// Appending DOMStrings
parent.append('Hello world') // Works fine
parent.appendChild('Hello world') // Throws error

const parent = document.createElement('div');
const child = document.createElement('p');
const childTwo = document.createElement('p');
parent.append(child, childTwo, 'Hello world'); // Works fine
parent.appendChild(child, childTwo, 'Hello world');
// Works fine, but adds the first element and ignores the rest

const parent = document.createElement('div');
const child = document.createElement('p');
const appendValue = parent.append(child);
console.log(appendValue) // undefined
const appendChildValue = parent.appendChild(child);
console.log(appendChildValue) // <p><p>

    In cases where you can use .appendChild, you can use .append but not vice versa.

    .appendChild - single item , no text/strings, can return a value when assigned to a variable.

    Creating multiple elements with loops

                      
<ul id="rangers"></ul>
    Create elements by looping through arrays
                      
var powerRangers = [
  "Jason Lee Scott", 
  "Kimberly Hart", 
  "Zack Taylor", 
  "Trini Kwan", 
  "Billy Cranston"
]

var rangersList = document.getElementById("rangers")
// classic
for (let i = 0; i < powerRangers.length; i++){
  let newListItem = document.createElement('li')
  newListItem.textContent = powerRangers[i]
  rangersList.append(newListItem)
}

// for...of
for (let rangerName of powerRangers){
  let newListItem = document.createElement('li')
  newListItem.textContent = rangerName
  rangersList.append(newListItem)
}

// innerHTML note +=  add to, don't override
for (var i = 0; i < powerRangers.length; i++) {
  rangersList.innerHTML += "<li>" + powerRangers[i] +"</li>"
}
    Create elements by looping through objects
                      
var powerRangers = [
  {name: "Jason Lee Scott", color: "Red"}, 
  {name: "Kimberly Hart", color: "Pink"}, 
  {name: "Zack Taylor", color: "Black"}, 
  {name: "Trini Kwan", color: "Yellow"}, 
  {name: "Billy Cranston", color: "Blue"},
  {name: "Tommy Oliver", color: "Green"}
]

var rangersList = document.getElementById("rangers")

for (let i = 0; i < powerRangers.length; i++){
  let newListItem = document.createElement('li')
  newListItem.style.color = powerRangers[i].color
  newListItem.textContent = powerRangers[i].name + " - " + powerRangers[i].color
  rangersList.append(newListItem)
}

      Event Listeners

      This will log every webpage event as it happens.

                        
// ALL EVENTS ARE BELONG TO US             
Object.keys(window).forEach(key => {
  if (/^on/.test(key)) {
      window.addEventListener(key.slice(2), event => {
          console.log(event.type);
      });
  }
});

      Basic event listener button (anonymous function)

                        
var button = document.getElementById("button")

button.addEventListener("click", function() {
    console.log("The button was clicked!")
})

      Clearer code. function declared first. 

                        
var button = document.getElementById("button")

function handleButtonClick() {
    console.log("The button was clicked!")
}

button.addEventListener("click", handleButtonClick)

      Warning Don't do whats below. The function will fire on page load because () means it will be immediately evoked.

                        
button.addEventListener("click", handleButtonClick())

      Event listeners can be removed as well as added. Use the same syntax as add.

                        
button.addEventListener("click", handleButtonClick)
button.removeEventListener("click", handleButtonClick)

      Summary

      Break it down.

      Get elements by whatever means. (ids if poss)

      Create function.

      Assign event listener to element. Give it a) the specific Event (click) and b) said Function as parameters.

      Create element from input value
                        
let btn = document.getElementById('btn')
let inputBox = document.getElementById('input-box')
let inputHolder = document.getElementById('input-holder')

function handleBtnClick() {
    console.log(inputBox.value)
    
    let para = document.createElement('p')
    para.textContent = inputBox.value
    inputHolder.append(para)
}

btn.addEventListener('click', handleBtnClick)

      Your Personality in Emojis

      .unshift()
      .push()
      .shift()
      .pop()

      Robert's Emojis

      üß† üë®‚Äçüéì üï∫ üëû ü¶Ç üåû üê≤ ü•ë üé± ‚úàÔ∏è üïπ üí£ ü™ì

                      
<div id="myEmoji-app">
  <h1>Robert's Emojis</h1>   
  <div id="emoji-container"></div>
  <input type="text" id="emoji-input" placeholder="type an emoji üéâ">
  <div class="buttons-wrapper">
      <button id="unshift-btn">Add to beginning (unshift)</button>
      <button id="push-btn">Add to end (push)</button>
  </div>
  <div class="buttons-wrapper">
      <button id="shift-btn">Remove from beginning (shift)</button>
      <button id="pop-btn">Remove from end (pop)</button>
  </div>
</div>

      Summary

      Break it down. Separate your thinking.

      The emojis array is is a const variable. It can be added to, but not changed. It will always be an array.

      We reset the emojiContainer's html content NOT the array with renderEmojis().

      In the loop:

      • create element
      • apply textContent
      • append to container

      Call the function straight away to render the original set, then add it to all the eventListeners.

                      
const myEmojis = ["üññ", "üé≤", "üéÆ", "üéû", "‚úèÔ∏è", "ü¶ë"]

function renderEmojis() {
  const emojiContainer = document.getElementById("emoji-container")
  emojiContainer.innerHTML = ""
  for (let i = 0; i < myEmojis.length; i++) {
    const emoji = document.createElement('span')
    emoji.textContent = myEmojis[i]
    emojiContainer.append(emoji)
  }
}

renderEmojis() //reset array

// Add
const pushBtn = document.getElementById("push-btn")
pushBtn.addEventListener("click", function(){
  const emojiInput = document.getElementById("emoji-input")
  if (emojiInput.value) { // if true, 
    myEmojis.push(emojiInput.value)
    emojiInput.value = "" // reset input value
    renderEmojis()
  }
})

const unshiftBtn = document.getElementById("unshift-btn")
unshiftBtn.addEventListener("click", function(){
  const emojiInput = document.getElementById("emoji-input")
  if (emojiInput.value) {
    myEmojis.unshift(emojiInput.value)
    emojiInput.value = ""
    renderEmojis()
  }
})

// Remove
const popBtn = document.getElementById("pop-btn")
popBtn.addEventListener("click", function(){
  myEmojis.pop()
  renderEmojis()
})

const shiftBtn = document.getElementById("shift-btn")
shiftBtn.addEventListener("click", function(){
  myEmojis.shift()
  renderEmojis()
})

      Diary App

      .preventDefault()
      function(event)

      Things Learned

      • html - border: unset;
      • submit is an event like 'click' and can be used when the eventListener is on a form
        entryForm.addEventListener('submit', addEntryToDom)
      • getElementsByClassName() returns an HTMLCollection, access by using bracket notation
        entryTextbox[0].value
      • Add a class to an element with classList :
        classList.add('single-entry')
        or className
        entryDiv.className = 'single-entry'
      • required can be added to a form element for entry to be required when submit is pressed.
      • querySelector will only return the first element it finds.

      My Personal Diary

      #entryForm ↓


      #entries ↓

      .entries-nav ↓

                      
const entryForm = document.getElementById('entryForm');
const entriesSection = document.querySelector('#entries');
const entryTextbox = document.querySelector('.entry-textbox');
const entriesNav = document.querySelector('.entries-nav');

let count = 1; // button numbering

function addEntryToDom(event) {
  
    // Create entry div
    event.preventDefault(); // stop page refresh
    const entryDiv = document.createElement('div');
    entryDiv.className = 'single-entry'; // assign class
    entryDiv.innerText = entryTextbox.value;
    entryDiv.style.display = 'none'; // hide div
    entriesSection.appendChild(entryDiv);
    entryTextbox.value = ''; // reset textarea
    
    // Create Buttons
    const displayEntryButton = document.createElement('button');
    displayEntryButton.className = 'display-entry-button';
    displayEntryButton.innerText = count;
    entriesNav.appendChild(displayEntryButton);
    
    // Add Listeners to Buttons
    displayEntryButton.addEventListener('click', function() {
      // Grab all just created entries
      const allEntries = document.querySelectorAll('.single-entry');
      // cycle through and hide all entries
      for (let i= 0; i < allEntries.length; i++) {
        allEntries[i].style.display = 'none';
      }
      // Show individual entry
      entryDiv.style.display = 'block';        
    })
    count++ // Increment to button two etc.
}

entryForm.addEventListener('submit', addEntryToDom)

      Interview Questions to Ask

      • Automatic Semicolon Insertion (ASI)? Semicolons to use or not to use
      • CSS House Style grouping?
